Award.AwardTitle: Midwest Regional Robert Noyce Connections 2017, 2018, 2019: Strengthening the Network for Teacher Learning at the Intersection of High-Quality and High-Need

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Midwest Regional Robert Noyce Connections convening will strengthen connections among funded Noyce projects in the Midwest region through expanding impact from the local areas influenced by the individual projects to a larger region throughout the Midwest. The Midwest region includes more than 62 active Noyce projects across 15 states (Arkansas, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, North Dakota, Ohio, Oklahoma, South Dakota, and Wisconsin). Specific goals of the project include: (1) increasing the personal and professional connections among Midwest Noyce project members and Noyce Scholars across the region and (2) enhancing the scholarship of teaching and learning among Noyce projects and scholars. Project goals will be accomplished through facilitating an annual regional Noyce conference in 2017, 2018, and 2019 in addition to a suite of year-round networking activities for Robert Noyce project personnel and participants in the Midwestern region.

The three conferences will bring together Noyce investigators, pre-service and in-service Noyce Scholars, school district personnel, and project evaluation and assessment experts to share lessons learned and use lessons learned to impact the larger Noyce community. Each annual conference will draw approximately 200 participants from the Midwest region. Year-round activities will support the building of strong communities of practice by providing additional opportunities for Noyce personnel and Noyce Scholars to learn and communicate with one another through social networking and other connecting activities. This project will provide a continuing opportunity for the STEM education community to develop high quality evidence-based communities of practice in areas of high need via the annual Midwest Regional Noyce Connections in 2017, 2018, and 2019.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program encourages talented science, technology, engineering, and mathematics majors and professionals to become K-12 teachers of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) by responding to the critical need for highly effective K-12 STEM teachers.

One need recognized by NSF is the need for projects to share not only programmatic results, but also individual lessons and ideas between projects as the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship programs develop. This Robert Noyce regional conference brings together novice teachers to meet with others and build a community of practice. The primary goal of Strengthening the Network for Teacher Learning at the Intersection of High-Quality and High-Need was to sustain and strengthen a network of peer support for Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship project personnel and scholars across the Midwest, thereby improving Noyce program effectiveness throughout the region, and facilitating growth of Noyce programs towards the goal of supplying high quality teachers of STEM to high-needs areas. In order to accomplish this goal, we pursued the following three objectives:

Objective 1:  Build on the partnerships and networking from the Noyce Conference grants of 2014 and 2015 to develop evidence-based learning communities among Noyce teachers.

Objective 2:  Increase the personal and professional connections among Midwest Noyce project members and Noyce Scholars across the region.

Objective 3: Enhance the scholarship of teaching and learning among Noyce projects and scholars.

Each year we added a specific conference theme which led to this fourth objective:

Objective 4: Developing strategies for bringing experiential math and science teaching to high needs schools.

 

Intellectual Merit:

The project allowed NSF to fully leverage the expertise and experiences of active Noyce projects across the Midwest by providing the platform to support across-project collaborations. The hosting of regional conferences allowed for sharing of ideas and expertise across projects, and the other activities (including workshops, webinars, and online communication) provided additional professional development and community-building opportunities for those associated with Midwest Noyce projects. Noyce projects share a dedication to improving mathematics and science teaching and learning in high-need Midwest districts, thus sharing expertise and building a stronger professional community among Noyce projects helped participants better access and utilize the shared expertise of the Noyce community.

Broader Impacts:

The conferences and accompanying suite of activities provided a network of peer support to Noyce Teacher Scholarship project personnel and Noyce Scholars, which supported the improvement of program effectiveness throughout the states in the Midwest. Sustaining professional networks of practice among the Noyce Scholars during their professional growth as beginning teachers in high-need classrooms at urban and rural schools is expected to be an important factor in their overall satisfaction and long-term persistence in diverse classrooms and the teaching profession.

In 2017, we held the annual conference in St. Louis with a total of 153 attendees representing 73 current and expired Robert Noyce awards. We initiated a series of participant-initiated activities that continued throughout the subsequent year in which we supported pairs of teachers from difference Noyce projects working together to implement new STEM lessons.  Our support consists of advice and funds to support innovative activities aimed at teaching the Mathematical Practices (MPs) of the Common Core or the Science and Engineering Practices (SEPs) of the Next Generation Science Standards. Finally, we hosted a series of webinars  to support teacher groups as they decide how to design and implement new lessons.

In 2018,  we had over 200 attendees (191 registered Noyce-related participants and over 30 guest presenters and panelists) at the annual conference, an increase of over 30%. We ran two subgrant competitions  with a total of 35 people attended the two subgrant webinars held for each competition in the preceding months before the submission deadlines. We  received 15 proposals for the participant-initiated activities. All proposals were able to show evidence of connections to the previous two conferences by proposing activities in classrooms local to their homes that aligned with site visits held during the conferences. Of those 15, six were able to evidence of how they had already used ideas from the Annual Conference in their 12 respective classrooms (each proposal is composed of two attendees and their classrooms) in the subsequent month since the conference.

The final 2019 annual conference had 225 attendees (215 registered Noyce-related participants and 10 guest presenters and panelists). Of the 215 Noyce related participants we had 60 PIs/Co-PIs, 80 Scholars, 68 Fellows, and 7 Noyce Alumni. We ran two subgrant competitions with a total of 24 people attended the two subgrant webinars held for each competition in the preceding months before the submission deadlines. We received 8 proposals all of which were able to show evidence of connections to the 2017, 2018, 2019 Midwest Noyce Conferences by proposing activities in classrooms local to their homes that aligned with site visits held during the conferences.
